subject: Re: [junit] UI testing am I being lazy?
msgSnippet: ... I don t like to write End to End tests; however, when someone returns me a defect, I have to admit that I missed something, and to punish myself, I do
messageBody:
Jonathan Oddy wrote:

> Dear All,
>
> A while ago I started looking at using one of the frameworks available for
> testing UI code (of a traditional desktop app) and starting using one
> (abbot). Primarily I used it to help test drive the implementation of
> various listeners required within a couple of dialogs I was writing. Whilst
> slowing down the unit test process (because it renders a UI and "robots" the
> user control) it's worked pretty well for me.
>
> Now I come to the validation process and I have received a number of bugs to
> fix (no big deal) but my question is how much should I drive my bug fixing?
> Normally (prior to abbot) I'd dig about my code to locate the appropriate
> code, create a test case (or cases) to highlight the bug and drive the fix
> appropriately. Now I have a UI fault that is easy to reproduce - and I've
> created a test case using abbot to highlight the fault, and can now dig
> through the code and fix it... but... this fault (as with a couple of other
> UI faults) resolves down to a failing implementation of some
> DocumentListener logic.
>
> So should I (would you) keep TDD the fix via the high level UI test case, or
> drill down and write "lower" level test cases for the DocumentListener
> implementation. The former helps solve the current bug, the later also
> fixes the bug but has better coverage of the listener (which could be/is
> reused)? Or should I duplicate the test to test both the UI working
> correctly and the listener being implemented correctly? I don't like the
> idea of duplication, and I prefer using non UI tool testing (because of the
> quicker round trip effect), but it seems that I probably do need both tests,
> or am I missing something?

I don't like to write End to End tests; however, when someone returns me
a defect, I have to admit that I missed something, and to punish myself,
I do things I don't like. I do this:

1. write a failing end to end test that shows the defect
2. test-drive the fix

Do you need both tests? No. But in the long run, and as a general
practice, you /want/ both tests.
